benchmark_details.name: A Law Reasoning Benchmark for LLM with Tree-Organized Structures
benchmark_details.overview: We propose a transparent law reasoning schema enriched with hierarchical factum probandum, evidence, and implicit experiences, along with a challenging task to create a hierarchical reasoning structure from a textual case description. We introduce the first crowd-sourced dataset for this task, enabling comprehensive evaluation.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To enable transparent and accountable AI-assisted law reasoning through structured evidence analysis and fact determination.

data.source: Crowd-sourced data from legal case descriptions available on the China Judgement Online Website.
data.annotation: Crowdsourced via law school students and professionals, ensuring quality through two-phase methodology including automated annotation and human refinement.

methodology.calculation: Metrics calculated based on predicted and actual outcomes related to factual and evidential reasoning.
methodology.interpretation: Performance evaluated based on the accuracy of law reasoning structures generated.
methodology.baseline_results: Compared with baseline models including ChatGLM-6B, LexiLaw, and others.
methodology.validation: Cross-validation with multiple annotator reviews for reliability.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All data sourced from publicly available records with no personal identifiers.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: All participants informed and consented voluntarily.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.compliance_with_regulations: Exercise of ethical principles per Declaration of Helsinki.
